ORAL ANSWERS TO QUESTIONS

COTTAGE INDUSTRIES
(Encouragement of)


    1. Mr Ang Nam Piau asked the Minister for National Development and

Column: 1214

Communications, in order to encourage cottage industries, if he will consider granting approval to persons who have been using a portion or the whole of dwelling-houses, chicken-huts, pigsties, etc., for manufacturing to continue their industries.

Column: 1215



    The Senior Minister of State for National Development (Dr Tan Eng Liang) (for the Minister for National Development and Communications): Mr Speaker, Sir, the question whether or not planning approval will be granted to use the whole or part of dwelling-houses, chicken-huts, pigsties, etc, for cottage industries will depend on the merits of each case. In evaluating each case the following factors are taken into consideration:-

    (i) The location of the premises;

    (ii) The nature and scale of the industry;

    (iii) The condition of the surrounding development;

    (iv) The Master Plan zoning of the area;

    (v) The current policy, if any, affecting the siting of such industries.

    All the above factors have to be carefully considered before a decision is made on each case, as once a decision is made to allow an industry in a particular area, a precedent is set for future industries to be so established in that area.

    To encourage cottage industries, the Housing and Development Board and the Jurong Town Corporation are putting up small terrace flatted type of factories for sale or rental for such industries.

    Mr Ang Nam Piau (Thomson): Mr Speaker, Sir, will the Senior Minister of State consider granting approval to persons to continue to use a portion or the whole of their dwelling-houses, chicken-huts and pigsties for manufacturing, if they have been engaged in this business for more than 20 years?

    Dr Tan Eng Liang: Mr Speaker, Sir, I think a distinction will have to be made as to whether the industry is on TOL or whether it is on a permanent basis. Where a change of use is involved, it is normally given to an existing user. But I do not know in what context the Member for Thomson is speaking. I think what he is implying is that certain types of industries are carried out in places like chicken-huts, pigsties and dwelling-houses, and whether they can continue. That is definitely not in order because, as I have mentioned, the most

Column: 1216

important factor is the zoning requirements. I have mentioned the precedent that will be created and, therefore, it would be impossible to control, say, other types of housing whose occupants would also want, for one reason or another, a change of use. Sir, the merits of each case will have to be seriously considered.

    If it is just a minor requirement, approval may be given. For example, previously we have discussed the situation where if a woman uses her dwelling house to make dresses and she owns two sewing machines, on that basis if she has been told that there is a change of use of the place then, of course, discretion has got to be exercised. She can argue her case out and say that it is probably not a change of use. But where a person wants a permit for a change of use to enable him to undertake certain cottage industries, I think, on grounds of planning approval, it is not in order.

    Mr Hwang Soo Jin (Jalan Kayu): Mr Speaker, Sir, I am not sure whether the Senior Minister of State is aware that the zoning criterion has been relied upon rather inflexibly by his Department. I have a recent case where a person was doing business frying kropok in his house. This was considered by the Department to be an industry, and he was given notice to stop doing it,

    Dr Tan Eng Liang: Mr Speaker, Sir, from the Planning Department's point of view, zoning is absolutely necessary if we really want to prevent indiscriminate types of activities going on in any particular area. As I have stated in the example which the Member for Jalan Kayu has mentioned, perhaps discretion could be exercised here. I share his sentiment that if the business is not intensive the Planning Authority could have exercised some flexibility here. But from the general overall Master Planning point of view, zoning is important. If we want to control the proper development of activities, then it is absolutely clear that there should be no compromise. But I do concede that flexibility could be exercised in cases of that nature.

Column: 1217



    Mr Hwang Soo Jin: Mr Speaker, Sir, I wonder whether the Senior Minister of State would consider providing certain flexibility in certain zones. For instance, in an Agricultural zone, you might provide that certain clean industries may be permitted. The zoning of areas was done quite a few years back and I do not think it has been reviewed for some time.

    Dr Tan Eng Liang: Mr Speaker, Sir, with regard to the overall Master Plan, it is agreed that it was done many years ago. But although we are supposed to upgrade the Master Plan every five years, I can assure the Member that it is being upgraded on a periodical basis, perhaps on an annual or bi-ennial basis.

    As to his suggestion of an adjustment to a particular zone, that is being done. For example, in the Agricultural zone, we have specifically introduced what is called a rural centre zone, in areas such as Jalan Kayu and Punggol. The idea of introducing a rural centre area is to ensure that certain activities, like shopping or perhaps even some form of light industries, could be undertaken. We also do allow in between the zones what we call a "mixed zone". In fact, we do allow in the Mixed zone, housing and light industries to be mixed together. We also allow specifically obnoxious industries to be located in certain areas where such activities could be carried out. In other words, I am saying that although the overall zoning policy is being followed, wherever necessary, modifications are made to the Master Plan to incorporate ideas of that nature.

LOADING AND UNLOADING OF GOODS FROM VEHICLES
(Relaxation of restriction)


    2. Mr Ho See Beng asked the Minister for National Development and Communications, in view of the ease of traffic on the roads within the Central Business District between the hours of 7.30 a.m. and 10.15 a.m., whether he will consider allowing the loading and unloading of goods to be carried out in places where

Column: 1218

these have been prohibited, for instance, North Bridge Road and Victoria Street.

    The Senior Minister of State for Communications (Mr Ong Teng Cheong) (for the Minister for National Development and Communications): Mr Speaker, Sir, the prohibition of loading and unloading of goods from vehicles parked at the side of certain roads is necessary because of a number of factors, for example, traffic conditions, physical terrain and the capacity of the road and the need to facilitate the flow of public transport vehicles. Presently the "No Stopping" restriction, which also restricts loading and unloading, is in operation along some busy roads within the Central Business District. The purpose of creating such clear ways is to avoid sterilisation of traffic lanes and obstruction of roads by goods vehicles during peak hours. This restriction is only operative from 7.30 a.m. to 9.30 a.m. and 4.30 p.m. to 7.00 p.m. from Mondays to Fridays and from 7.30 a.m. to 9.30 a.m. and 11.30 a.m. to 2.30 p.m. on Saturdays. There is no restriction on Sundays and public holidays.

    The Registry of Vehicles, the Traffic Police and the Public Works Department (Roads Branch) are now looking into the possibility of lifting the restriction along certain roads within the Central Business District between the hours of 7.30 a.m. and 10.15 a.m. In this review priority will continue to be given to facilitating the movement of buses. Loading and unloading will be allowed only if traffic flow is not impeded as a result.

    Mr Ho See Beng (Khe Bong): Mr Speaker, Sir, may I ask the Senior Minister of State, when he received this question, why did the Department concerned not take the trouble to do a survey of North Bridge Road and Victoria Street?

    Mr Ong Teng Cheong: Sir, I am sure that when the scheme of clear ways was introduced as early as 1974, surveys had been conducted. With the introduction of the Area Licensing Scheme in 1975 the situation perhaps has changed slightly for the better, and that is why a review is going on at this stage.

SIN MING INDUSTRIAL ESTATE
(Request for Community Centre)


    3. Mr Ang Nam Piau asked the Minister for Culture and Science and Technology whether it is planned to build a community centre near the Housing and Development Board flats at Sin Ming Road.

    The Minister for Culture and Science and Technology (Mr Jek Yeun Thong): Mr Speaker, Sir, the Member for Thomson must be referring to the Sin Ming Industrial Estate which, according to the information provided by the Housing and Development Board, has about 1,170 units of residential flats. In view of the small population size and the availability of three existing centres in the Thomson constituency which are within 1.6 km from the Estate, a new centre has not been planned for this area.

DAILY-RATED EMPLOYEES IN SCHOOLS
(Emplacement on monthly-rated terms)


    4. Mr Ch'ng Jit Koon asked the Minister for Home Affairs and Education (a) how many daily-rated employees there are in the various schools, giving breakdown figures according to the different categories of posts; and (b) if his Ministry will consider taking steps to convert such employees to monthly-rated employees.

    The Senior Minister of State for Education (Mr Chai Chong Yii) (for the Minister for Home Affairs and Education): Mr Speaker, Sir, there are altogether 14 daily-rated employees currently deployed to the schools. Of these, eight are unskilled workmen: seven deployed in primary schools and one in a secondary school. The other six daily-rated employees are watchmen, of whom three are in primary schools and three in secondary schools. Unskilled workmen are normally employed on daily-rated terms not only in the Ministry of Education but also in other Government Ministries and departments. The question of emplacing them on monthly-rated terms is one that would therefore have to be considered in relation to the Government service as a

Column: 1220

whole and not only in relation to the Education Ministry. In the case of the six daily-rated watchmen, however, they have been employed on such terms temporarily and may be considered for emplacement on monthly-rated terms subsequently.

    Mr Ch'ng Jit Koon (Tiong Bahru)(In Mandarin): Mr Speaker, Sir, I agree with the Minister of State's answer that in other Government departments there are also daily-rated workers. But in the case of daily-rated workers in schools it is different because they have longer holidays. Being daily-rated workers, they are not paid during the long holidays. I would like to ask the Minister of State whether he would consider giving the daily-rated workers some other work to do during the school vacation.

    Mr Chai Chong Yii: Mr Speaker, Sir, it is true that the daily-rated workers sometimes have nothing to do during the school vacation. But we do try to give them whatever jobs there are, possibly in schools. But unfortunately, it is not always possible, especially during the long vacation. Their number in schools is fairly small.

    Mr J. F. Conceicao (Katong): Sir, I beg to move,

    That the sum to be allocated for Head U be reduced by $10 in respect of subhead CBA 1101.

    I would just like to reflect a problem which has repeatedly been brought to my attention by my constituents. The drainage in the Tanjong Katong/Mountbatten Road as well as Poole Road, Parkstone Road, Goodman Road area is poor. This area is a well developed area with schools and residential

Column: 1221

dwellings and yet it is not uncommon to find the roadside drains full of stagnant water. This situation is worse when there is heavy rain. The roadside drains overflow and flood the adjacent roads and houses. Is it not possible for the experts in the Ministry to improve drainage and alleviate the flooding in this area?

    The Minister for Law and the Environment (Mr E. W. Barker): Mr Speaker, Sir, the Member is well aware that the area referred to is a low-lying area. In fact. Mountbatten Road was formerly known as Grove Road. Grove Road and the area referred to formed part of the Grove Estate. I do not know where the word "Grove" came from, probably from "mangrove". The Member should also be well aware that one-quarter of Singapore island is swampy. Hence the many reclamations which have taken place; the outstanding one being Jurong which was previously one big large swamp.

    As the Member has pointed out, the area he referred to is very well developed. In fact, the floods are controlled by tidal gates at the Geylang River. But that is all we can do. My experts tell me that they can suggest nothing except that the land be raised. If the land is raised the buildings must go up too. So I am afraid it must be just one big "NO". But the Member is not alone in his complaint because there are other parts of Singapore, like parts of Chinatown for instance, which are below high tide level and without any rain parts of Chinatown can come under water. So that is all I can say to the Member. My sympathies, but that is it.

    Head V -

    Mr P. Govindaswamy (Anson): Mr Speaker, Sir, I beg to move,

    That the sum to be allocated for Head V be reduced by $10 in respect of subhead AAA 1004*. (*The same amendment also stood in the name of Dr Ong Leong Boon).

    The Minister for Home Affairs is entrusted with the responsibility of internal security and law and order. The Internal Security Department comes under his Ministry and therefore it has the duty and responsibility to check on any dangerous elements in our midst. During the last few months the ISD has been doing an excellent job in actively tracking down and exposing many communists and anti-national elements in our midst. Its performance is indeed commendable. It appears there are a number of dangerous people living in our midst, whom the ISD has already detected and exposed. I would like to suggest that the ISD be expanded so that there could be a thorough check of all Government departments, schools and tertiary institutions, because at the moment we do not seem to know who is who.

    Sir, turning to the subject of drugs. Many Members have already spoken about the drug problem the trafficking and consumption of drugs in Singapore during the last decade. Yesterday a man died because of drug addiction. Even our laws too have been revised and the death penalty has been introduced for drug offences. Though the death penalty has been introduced, yet we do not see any appreciable decline in the trafficking of drugs. We have already heard that about 10 persons have been sentenced to death and about 30 others are still awaiting trial. I wonder what the authorities are doing to further stamp this menace of drug trafficking.

Column: 1223



    One way to solve the prevalent drug problem is to stringently control the entry and departure of foreigners. At present, foreigners can easily stay behind after the stipulated time and escape detection. Why not introduce entry control cards which could be used to detect anyone overstaying his visit? Perhaps peddlers and drug dealers could be dealt a severe blow if the entry of foreigners was controlled.

    Sir, as for drug abusers, what action is being taken against them and what rehabilitation is being given to them? I understand that many young boys and girls who indulge in drugs are not being properly rehabilitated in the detention camps.

    Quite often, after their release they commit the same offence and have to go back again for rehabilitation. There seems to be no proper rehabilitation of these young drug addicts to give up the habit of taking drugs. Why is this so?

    Could the Minister comment on this matter?

    The Chairman: Dr Ong is not speaking. Mr Chua.

    The Minister for Home Affairs and Education (Mr Chua Sian Chin): Mr Speaker, Sir, in reply to the Member for Anson, let me first take his comments on the ISD. First, the Member has commended the ISD for having done a good job in the last few months in tracking down and exposing communists and anti-national elements. I wish to thank him for his word of appreciation. I am sure the ISD officers concerned who had worked very hard would be very much encouraged, particularly when it is not very often that the Member for Anson gives bouquets in a debate in the Committee of Supply.

    However, Mr Speaker, Sir, to his suggestion that the ISD should be expanded to thoroughly check all Government departments, schools and tertiary institutions because "at the moment we do not know who is who", I would like to point out the difference between just identifying a person

Column: 1224

and identifying a communist or anti-national element in our midst. The Police or the ISD has little difficulty in identifying persons through identity cards, passports, finger prints, etc. However, identifying a person who is a communist or an anti-national element is quite a different matter. Firstly, these elements do not operate openly but in a clandestine manner. They go about their subversive activities by hiding their real intentions and objectives. When confronted, they will not voluntarily own up their involvement unless the ISD knows of their involvement and is able to confront them with evidence. Secondly, the ISD would require a very large pool of manpower to keep a watch on each and everyone in Government departments, schools or tertiary institutions in order to identify who are communists and anti-national elements and who are not.

    Sir, it will not be cost-effective and in most cases the checking will be a waste of effort and might even result in undue inconvenience and embarrassment. This, of course, is not desirable. The ISD has been able to identify communists and anti-national elements in these organisations through its intelligence work. Intelligence is also gathered largely from painstaking investigation and interrogation of detainees. For this work I agree that the ISD need more staff. In fact, the department is still in the midst of correspondence with the Ministry of Finance to get more staff.

    Sir, with regard to the other points on drug consumption and rehabilitation, I shall reply to them when the various subheads pertaining to the Central Narcotics Bureau are raised for discussion.

    Mr P. Govindaswamy: Sir, the reason why I praised the ISD is because I hope the officers will work hard. A drop of ink in a bucket of milk can spoil the whole milk. Therefore, the ISD should check each and every department. I repeat: a drop of ink can spoil a whole bucket of milk.

    Mr Conceicao: Sir, I beg to move,

    That the sum to be allocated for Head V be reduced by $10 in respect of subhead BAA 1101*. (* The same amendment also stood in the names of Messrs Teong Eng Siong and P. Govindaswamy.)

    I am speaking on this subhead, Sir, because the activity I am going to talk about was started on the basis of a proposal from Police Headquarters and is being monitored by Police Headquarters.

    I would like to refer to a joint Police NS/Special Constabulary project named Libra Project which is being conducted in a number of housing estates, including Kampong Arang /Jalan Batu which is in my constituency.

    It appears that this Libra Project has two principal aims: youth work and counselling as well as formation of neighbourhood committees, to foster greater neighbourliness. Sir, I think this project is experimenting with a praiseworthy attempt at giving NS Police and S.C. members a chance of participating in national service directed towards creative, good, praiseworthy social ends. I have followed the experiment with some interest, noticing the change of direction of emphasis caused by experience of the real situation on the ground led by those working in this Libra Project. I think the project deserves encouragement and help to make this police aim of service to youth achievable, hence contributing to good police/public relations. The project is still

Column: 1226

relatively embryonic in relation to what it could achieve.

    I would like to make one suggestion, however, which I hope will help the project avoid an unnecessary pitfall. This is in connection with the project's efforts at forming neighbourhood committees. May I suggest that such committees be formed through the CCC as sub-committees of the CCC and that good liaison be maintained with the Member of Parliament of the constituency concerned. This could well result in a pooling of resources and in such collaboration that would help further in the project's aim, because the proliferation of committees in housing estates, constituencies, may well add to the confusion of aims.

    Mr Teong Eng Siong (Sembawang)(In Mandarin): Sir, in recent years after a restructuring of the Police Force, there has been an improvement in the administration of the Police Force, resulting in greater peace and order in our society. However, there are still some shortcomings with the Police Force. According to complaints I have received, some people had occasion to make a report at a police station, but the policemen were not prepared to take their report saying that the Inspector in charge was not in. So they had to wait until his return. After about four hours of waiting, the Inspector in charge of the station did not return. So the complainants had wasted their time. I then enquired of the Police Department whether it was necessary to report only to an Inspector or a station head. The reply was, "No. Any ordinary police officer on duty can take down a complaint." This shows the policemen at the police station quoted above had not performed their duty properly.

    I have also received complaints that certain traffic policemen have abused their power by booking drivers at random. There is a mobile squad in the Traffic Police that specially deals with this. Sir, if they take measures to deal with speeding motorcyclists it is all right, but it is not right to flag down any driver who has not been

Column: 1227

speeding. Also, there have been complaints that some mobile squad personnel themselves have been speeding on the road, recklessly and dangerously. Their performance could well beat any racing motorcyclist. This is what they should not do because they are endangering other road users. So the authorities concerned should look into this matter. Police officers are people who enforce the law. So they themselves should not infringe any law.

    Generally speaking, the Police Force in our Republic has performed well with a high degree of efficiency. Their duty is to protect lives and property of our people. In order to increase the efficiency of our police and to promote better cooperation between the police and members of the public, I have several suggestions to make.

    In the past few years the police has been organising Police Weeks every year. The response has been good. It improves the relationship between the police and the public. Since it is good and useful, I would like to ask the Minister whether Police Weeks will continue to be organised. Personally, I think it should be held so as to build up a better relationship between the police and the people. Besides achieving better cooperation between the police and the people, I would like to ask the Minister whether the Police could organise an "Open House Day" for members of the public to visit police establishments. This can be done also through community centres and other public centres because during "Open House Day" members of the public will learn how to liaise with the police in the event of a crime or accident. In this way the people can understand the work of the police better and on the other hand it will promote cooperation between the people and the police. This is a good objective. In order to achieve it concrete steps must be taken. Senior police officers themselves should set a good example in promoting this cooperation. I feel that every policeman of the rank of Inspector and above should frequently take part in social and community activities. For instance, they should take part in activities conducted by community centres in the various

Column: 1228

constituencies. The police officer in charge of the constituency should be present. This will promote a better understanding of the relationship between the police and the public, thereby removing any bias that exists between them. There is a feeling that the police are "unapproachable ones". Therefore, with greater cooperation and understanding between the police and the people, members of the public would dare to make reports to the police if anything happens.

    Secondly, I would like to ask the Minister whether he would set up in every police district a public complaints bureau at a convenient place to facilitate complaints from the public, because ordinary people are not used to complain or to report any case to the police, particularly when there are police officers who are haughty and arrogant. So the people dare not go and report to a police station. The officer in charge in the complaints bureau should be bilingual or even multi-lingual in order to facilitate an understanding of the complaint.

    Thirdly, I would like to ask the Minister whether he will consider increasing the number of police patrol cars in order to increase efficiency. At the moment I feel that the number of patrol cars is not sufficient. Not so long ago at my meet-the-people session a voter complained to me that somebody threw stones at his house. I telephoned for a police patrol car but it turned up only half an hour later. I asked him why he took such a long time to come. He said. "I am sorry, but we are short of patrol cars." So I appeal to the Minister to increase the number of patrol cars, as it will not only meet the need to maintain law and order but also increase the efficiency of the police.

    The fourth point is the white cross-lines drawn by the side of many roads. Recently somebody complained to me that because he was not familiar with the meaning of the white cross-lines on the road, he ran into them and was fined $50. According to the Police authority's explanation to him, such white cross-lines on the road mean that they represent stones. If one runs over the white cross-lines it means that one is knocking

Column: 1229

against the stone. So it is a traffic offence and the driver will be fined. This is really funny. I do not quite understand the use of this road sign at all. Some people commented that perhaps this is because the traffic police want more revenue that they induce drivers to run over such lines drawn on narrow roads. During peak hours when traffic is very heavy people would inevitably run over the white cross-lines. So the traffic policemen standing by the road side would take down the car numbers and fine the motorists. I would like the Minister to look into the matter.
